content.rendered:
The Salesforce Events 2020 is live!! That’s right Ohana, it wouldn’t be my blog if I wasn’t talking about events and how we connect and get together as humans.  For real, we get out from behind the keyboard, and even leave the HOUSE!!! I know, it’s crazy, but for Ohana, many of us don’t just go across town, we will travel around the world.

So Salesforce Events, what are they? what do you do at them? where are they? who goes to them? Let’s just take this one step at .a time.  Back in 2017 I started tracking events in a google sheet so that I could have a doc with all events in one place, I shared this out and have been doing so since, and now the Salesforce Events 2020.

What Are Events?

There are a few types of events that are tracked on the Salesforce Events spreadsheet:

Salesforce Events

Salesforce events, like the big ones, that are put on by Salesforce, run by Salesforce, and a 100% Salesforce thing.  You can submit to speak during the CFP, have coaching before your presentation with

a handler, and these are BIG conferences – Dreamforce (SF), TrailheaDX (SF), and Connections (Chicago). They are multiple days, have a number of sponsors, keynotes, big announcements happen here. Great place to see lots of people for short amounts of time, but you will miss people at DF.  There are tons of people at Dreamforce, it’s hard to see everyone

World Tours

World Tours, these are small Salesforce events that are local.  They are run by Salesforce, have speakers, and are usually a one day event. City based World Tours usually have a couple sessions going at a time, they are great to get an introduction to the community and locals in the industry.  WT’s are much easier to navigate than larger events, but have lots of the same content, but since they are just one day, it’s limited.

Community (AKA Dreamin) Events

Dreamin Events, these are run by the local community – people like you that just want to bring others in Salesforce together to connect and learn. They are smaller, 1-2 days most of the time.  They have a call for speakers before the event for people to submit.  A few partners are there with info – these events are sponsored by partners and your ticket, so to keep ticket costs low and help you find valuable resources for Salesforce, Partners are there to save the day. They are locally held, but open to all, and they are ALL OVER THE WORLD!!! These are amazing ways to not only meet your local Ohana, but to see the world with Salesforce.

Personally, I’ve crossed off Southern to Northern Ireland (Road trip from Dublin to Bundoran for Surf Force ), Casablanca, Morocco (North Africa Dreamin), Amsterdam (YeruDreamin), and in March Alberta, Canada (Banff Dreamin) – then, should everything work out, in May to New Zealand (for Kiwi Dreaming) with community events.  Seriously, you can see the world with Salesforce events. They are everywhere, from the weirdness of Portland, OR to heartland with Minneapolis, MN, to the home of the Clash with London, United Kingdom, to the first ever European Dev event in Warsaw, Poland to the Noida, India to Singapore, to Tokyo, Japan to so many others!!

Misc

Other, Non-Profit Sprints, Salesforce Days in Cities, Trailblazer days, anything besides user group events that is large enough to track is added through out the year.  You can always find User Group meetings at https://trailblazercommunitygroups.com/.

Attend Events

How to Choose

Events are attended by us, the Salesforce Community.  Now, how to pick which event to attend, that’s something that should be done with care.  When picking events you need to think about a few things:

  1. What is work willing to cover?
  2. Am I willing to self fund?
  3. Do I want to submit a session? (Speakers usually get a free pass to the event)
  4. Where is the event in relation to me?
  5. When is the event and how does it align with my project timeline(s)? (Eg if the event is the day of your year long project go live, then you will probably want to skip that event and do a different one)
  6. What is the event theme and am I interested? (Eg. If the event in your area is about non-profits and you don’t do non-profit work, ever, then you might want to consider a different event)

Talk to Your Boss

So, reviewing the questions above should help you pick the events you want to go to.  Personally, I self fund my international events and some of my US events.  I really like going to events, and that’s awesome, nothing wrong with wanting to spend my time doing

Salesforce things and meeting new Salesforce people and learning new Salesforce things, but I do not expect my employer to pay for me to fly all over the world for every single event I want to go to, that wouldn’t be realistic.  So, talk to your boss, see what they will

cover and see what can be worked out.  Maybe they will cover x number of events, or maybe they will do learning time vs PTO, or maybe they will do event expenses – you never know til you ask.

Now we are almost ready for an event, we have permission from work, they have agreed to cover a few community events (yay!!) now we need to find out which one to go to.  This is where the Twitter, the event website, the session list, and how the event aligns with your projects comes into play.  Lots of events have sessions that people are trying out for DF or have done at DF, that’s something to keep in mind. This content is good so you don’t want to spend the whole event staring at your laptop working. Make sure that you can spend time in the sessions and with the others connecting.  The community events are priceless for connections. Use the Salesforce Events 2020 list to help simplify your search.

Salesforce Events 2020

So, where is this document with these events I keep hyping up?

Well, couple more things….

First off, if you want to talk about events, you can talk about them on the Twitters, here is my Salesforce Community Events Twitter List, which I try to catch all the new Dreamin’ AKA Community events that come up and add their handles to the list.  Second, on #OhanaSlack we have a number of event channels, the event channels all start with event-, just click on channels to add once you join. Third, the Trailblazer Community, some events have Chatter Groups, you can join even if you can’t attend to keep up on what’s up.

Salesforce Events 2020 Document

 

And don’t forget to see me at #BanffDreamin (@BanffDreamin) and #TrueNorthDreamin in Canada where I will be speaking about Community Cloud in March and April! Looking forward to seeing you at other events this year off the Salesforce Events 2020 list!
